Returning to FPS games after a few years and upgrading all my peripherals at the same time, I feel that Aimlabs has definetely helped me to get my aim more consistent and reliable in games. Also testing your aiming skills in different scenarios and training with increasing difficulty is also fun at least for me. I dont think this will make you aiming god in any game, but it can definetely help in getting your aim more consistent and increase your skill with the mouse at least to a pretty high poin.

here would be where i would start 20 min for a month try out sens randomizer and try out drills. Then make your own playlist specialised for the game you want to work on and do that every day. They offer so much for free and i am debating getting premium. Aim/ crosshair placment dose not make you good at a game lick cod but it dose make you able to hit nasty flicks. It is satifying and i have noticed gains. Consitancy is the only way you will make gains. 5 min a day is better than 1 hour a week. Consitancy is key. This is your key to starting. Hope you enjoy this like i did.

Aimlabs ‚Äì The Best Aim Trainer!

If you want to get better at aiming in FPS games, Aimlabs just makes sense. It gives you all kinds of training scenarios‚Äîflick shots, tracking, target switching, you name it. You get real feedback and detailed stats, so you always know exactly what‚Äôs working and what isn‚Äôt.

The scenarios are straightforward, and you can tweak them however you like. Some workouts feel almost like a game, but they still push you to improve your reflexes and precision‚Äîskills you absolutely need for FPS games. Plus, Aimlabs is super easy to use, and there‚Äôs even a free version, so anyone can try it out.

Honestly, I‚Äôve seen a real difference in my own aim since I started using Aimlabs regularly. If you want to step up your game, I‚Äôd definitely give it a shot.

Pros:

Top-notch aim training

You can customize the practice

Clear stats and feedback

Free to use

Cons:

Doesn‚Äôt cover every single in-game situation

You‚Äôll still need to play real matches to see full progress

Rating: 9/10
Good game for practicing and improving your skills in games such as CS:GO or Valorant.
With Recent updates and improvements, aimlabs is awesome aim trainer

free to play game that sends you mice if you're good at it. 

11/10, love my free pro x superlight 2, thanks aimlabs <3

Aim Lab is one of the best tools out there for improving your aim across any FPS game. The training tasks cover everything‚Äîfrom flicking and tracking to reaction time and precision‚Äîso it‚Äôs easy to focus on exactly what you want to improve. The progress tracking is also super helpful; seeing your stats go up over time is really motivating.

The customization options are great too. You can adjust almost everything to match the sensitivity and feel of the game you normally play, which makes the practice much more effective. Plus, the community-made playlists keep the experience fresh.

Whether you‚Äôre a casual player trying to get more consistent or a competitive player aiming for high-level performance, Aim Lab is definitely worth using. It‚Äôs free, lightweight, and actually helps.

Aim Lab is hands-down one of the best tools to improve your aiming skills across FPS games. The variety of tasks helps you train every aspect of aim‚Äîflicks, tracking, speed, precision, reaction time, everything.

The progress tracking is super motivating, and the customization lets you tailor every scenario to match the game you play (Valorant, CS2, Apex, etc.). The devs keep updating it, and it runs smoothly even on low-end PCs.

Whether you're a beginner trying to get better or an experienced player looking to stay sharp, Aim Lab is absolutely worth having.

I downloaded Aimlabs to get better at FPS games.
Now I‚Äôm a god at shooting colorful floating orbs‚Ä¶ and still whiff full mags on a guy standing completely still in Counter-Strike.
Pros:


Tells me I‚Äôm in the ‚Äútop 3%‚Äù while I hard-stare at my Bronze rank.


‚ÄúJust one more scenario‚Äù has replaced ‚Äújust one more game.‚Äù


My tracking on tiny dots is insane. My tracking on enemies? Not found.


Free therapy in the form of graphs showing exactly how bad I am.


Robot voice is the only one that believes in me anymore.


Cons:


99% accuracy in Aimlabs, 9% accuracy in real matches.


I now know 437 ways to miss a target.


Friend: ‚ÄúYo, you playing?‚Äù
Me: ‚ÄúNo, I‚Äôm training.‚Äù Proceeds to get one-tapped in Valorant pistol round.


Every session ends with ‚ÄúYou improved!‚Äù and my brain replying ‚ÄúLiar.‚Äù


Overall:
Aimlabs turned me from a potato into a slightly seasoned wedge.
10/10
Would grind flicks, queue ranked, and instantly get humbled again.

Aim labs, and aim training in general is what you make of it. You can spend 1,000 hours in it and make no progress or spend 100 hours on it and double your cs rank. The key is getting started and staying consistent, which is great because aim labs is free and tracks your days scores and favorite scenarios. When people compare it to Kovvaks it may fall short. Aim labs is free and needs to monitize itself with skins, ai assistants, etc, its live service but that also means its continuously being worked on. Kovvaks is sleek, comfortable, and optimal, and $15 isn't a lot of money for a hobby you'll be spending 100s of hours on. But theres nothing wrong with aim labs, if you want to improve you need to seek the improvement from within, and use the tools you have. And Aim labs has 1v1s so I can destroy my friends so 10/10 would reccomend.

Aimlabs can be a useful tool in your toolbox‚Äîespecially if you want to sharpen the mechanical side of aiming (tracking, flicks, consistency). But:

It won‚Äôt replace playing the game itself or working on broader skills like positioning, map awareness, movement, crosshair placement.

Use it as a warm-up or supplementary diet, not the main meal.

If you‚Äôre tight on time (with montages, work at BLS, workouts etc.), focus first on in-game practice (deathmatch, aim duels) and then add Aimlabs if you feel your aim specifically is a limiting factor.

Be cautious if you‚Äôre considering the paid version‚Äîonly get it if you‚Äôre sure you‚Äôll use the extra features regularly and it‚Äôs giving you measurable benefit.

Overall: I‚Äôd rate Aimlabs for you as 7/10. It‚Äôs worth it ‚Äî but only if used smartly and in balance with other practice. If you treat it as a silver bullet, you‚Äôll probably be disappointed.

I recommend playing this for free and I do not recommend spending money on it, and I'll break down why. There's an "aim sensitivity finder" that the ads claim will improve your aim 49% faster if you use it, right? But think about how that data's taken. Aimlabs Pro is a bundle. If you get the sens finder, you get that whole bundle, so anyone who's using the sens finder is using the rest of that bundle too. That's a pretty huge bias. On top of that you have selection bias where maybe half the people who don't buy the bundle just straight up don't improve at all or even play for more than an hour. And on top of that, maybe the oldheads who don't want to spend money just don't improve as much, because they have less room to do so. New players who buy the shiny subscription might "improve way faster" just because they start at rock bottom. Aim trainers are good though, not just for practice but for adjusting your setup, warming up, etc.

gooooood for valorant
aimlaabs plus is worth it :)
for people who are bad at aiming and if people play this it wouldn't be so rage bait when your teammates cant aim in CS2 or Valorant
Brilliant training, clear analytics, and proper improvement to my aim. Well worth the time.

Aim Labs is a good program for practicing aim in shooting games. It has many exercises that work on accuracy, reaction time, and tracking. You can focus on the areas you need to improve, and it shows your progress over time so you can see how you are getting better.

The program can be adjusted to match the settings of the games you play. There are also different playlists created by the community, which helps keep the exercises varied. I have played similar aim-training games in the browser before, but this one is available with different game modes for esports titles like Counter-Strike, Valorant, R6S, and more. I have also used Refrag.gg long ago, which is a paid program for practicing Counter-Strike.

In conclusion, Aim Labs is helpful for both casual and competitive players. It is free, easy to run on most computers, and can help improve aiming skills with regular practice.

(I have about 23 hours on my alt account)
*At least for TF2 and Deadlock I didnt seem to notice a big increase in aim, but tbh I already practice a lot in those games. I think a newer gamer would find this very helpful. At least the free edition, doesnt really offer anything that would help me in the games i play, because those games have such different weapons and movement systems. Its better to just focus practicing within some of those games. 
-Deadlock for example, it already has built in systems to help you see how slow your soul denials are, with input lag, server lag, ect. There is no way to practice dash jump sliding into a wall jump heavy melee while trying to keep someone off your tail. So, some skills will always need to be practiced within the game. 
-TF2 has a lot of movement tech that can never really be practiced outside of that game, PLUS the community servers do an insane job and letting you practice.

IF your game is "Click first = win" then yeah, AIMLABs will help you a good bit. But so many games have such different settings/lag/responce, I will always recommend in game training.
Good free source for building skill and confidence in your aim. Good for warmups and any FPS player.

I think aimlabs is very easily the best aim trainer, I have  bought and tried multiple other aimtrainers (for e.g. kovaaks, aimbeasts, 3d aim trainer) and i've not had such a great user experience and actual functional use with those than i have with aimlabs, even though aimlabs is free compared to aimbeasts and kovaaks.

I‚Äôve spent some time with this game and honestly, it surprised me in a way I didn‚Äôt fully expect. I don‚Äôt want to sound dramatic, but there‚Äôs something oddly satisfying about how everything fits together ‚Äî not in some perfect, polished ‚Äúadvertisement‚Äù way, but more like a game that knows exactly what it wants to be and just‚Ä¶ goes for it.

The first thing I noticed is the atmosphere. Every part of the game ‚Äî the visuals, the sound, the pacing ‚Äî kind of blends into this feeling that you‚Äôre actually inside its world, even if you‚Äôre just casually playing. I know that sounds a bit clich√©, but it‚Äôs true. Sometimes it‚Äôs chaotic, sometimes slow, sometimes you‚Äôre just wandering around thinking ‚Äúok, what now?‚Äù but that‚Äôs honestly part of the charm. The game doesn‚Äôt try to rush you unless it actually needs to.

Gameplay-wise, it has this mix of familiar elements and small twists that keep things from feeling stale. Nothing groundbreaking, maybe, but it all works together in a way that feels natural. There were moments when I thought ‚Äúyeah, I‚Äôve seen this in other games,‚Äù but then the game throws in tiny details or unexpected interactions that make it stand out just enough. It‚Äôs the kind of thing you only notice after a few hours, when you start connecting the dots.

Performance has been mostly fine. A little rough spot here and there, but honestly, show me a game these days that doesn‚Äôt have something weird happening once in a while. Nothing game-breaking on my end, at least. You can clearly tell the developers put effort into this, even if a few edges are still a bit sharp. Again ‚Äî part of the charm.

What I really appreciate is that the game gives you space to play the way you want. Some people will rush through every objective, others will take their time exploring or messing around, and both approaches actually feel valid. I like games that don‚Äôt punish you for not following some ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù path.

Overall, I‚Äôd say this is one of those titles that grows on you the longer you play. It doesn‚Äôt try too hard to impress in the first five minutes ‚Äî instead it slowly builds its identity, layer by layer, until you suddenly realize you‚Äôve been playing way longer than you planned. If you‚Äôre looking for something that balances comfort with challenge, familiar mechanics with fresh touches, and a world that‚Äôs just fun to be in, then I genuinely think this one is worth giving a shot.

Would I recommend it?
Yeah, I would ‚Äî maybe not to everyone, because no game is for everyone, but definitely to anyone who likes getting lost in a game for a bit and discovering things at their own pace.

Yo, I just hopped into Aimlabs for my daily masochism session, and it's like a virtual firing squad where bots multiply faster than my regrets‚Äîtraining your aim to frag noobs while your social life flatlines in the corner! Clicking through Gridshot hoverboards and Spidershot nightmares, watching my accuracy climb from "potato" to "barely competent" as AI whispers "git gud" via analytics‚Äîfeels empowering until a leaderboard peek reveals cheaters hoarding prizes like they buried their victims. Playlists for Valorant or CS vibes? Cloned physics make it transfer seamlessly, but one whiffed flick and you're screaming at ghosts.

Fall 2025's got Dropshot battle royale chaos and Dodgebot revenge boss fights, with Logitech skins for that premium sweat‚Äî7k+ players grinding daily like it's therapy for our trigger fingers. 9/10. Free aim heaven‚Äîyour KD lives, but your sleep schedule gets a dirt nap!

It COULD BE a good tool but the program is more interested in stealing your money. 10 dollars a month to adjust your sensitivity! WTF! This pos feels more like a scam and/or a ripoff. And adding cosmetics and score board to justify the price is freakng stpd. This feels more like a scam than anything else.

For being free its okay, however i give a big thumbs down since its a subscription based program. I am not a fan of this practice. Im the pay once and use it type of person. But thats not the reason for the negative, if i crash in the menus while just trying to go from lesson to lesson  and the app itself just freezes on screen crashing itself, its just poorly designed and optimized. I cant in good faith say these devs deserve any money, its absurd to pay something monthly. I can get behind 50 or 20 bucks but 10 bucks a month. You think your WOW or what idk. I aint rich, sure i want my aim to get better but its not worth more then a game value at best. And for that reason as a shark i would say. For that reason, I'm out.

I used to really enjoy aimlabs, it was simple to use and I loved it, now it's riddled with ads and monthly subscriptions, there's no fluidity in the ui and the settings are a nightmare along with no easy use of mouse adjustment for the sensitivity which is the whole point of an aim trainer, just disapointing overall
i payed for a month now i cant login it gets laggy and it not straightf forward for me

Dog shit aim trainer. How u gonna make an aim trainer so unoptimized that even the lobby is stuttery. You cant get high scores cause the game just stutters the whole time. it never used to be this bad but with the most recent updates its almost unplayable. Ig its back to kovaks for me. L aim trainer dont even bother.
There are so many bugs in the task and playlist editor, that it was impossible to create a custom playlist that contains my own customized tasks.
If you wan to practice your general aim, is ok. But if you like playing a specific game like cs, the best way to make you aim better is by paying that game.

When the game launches it asks you weather you want to create an account or play offline with "some features" unavalable, I chose not to create an account because I don't see a reason to, however just a few clicks later I realized that for whatever reason the devs have made it so you actually CANNOT USE the aim-trainer gamemode if you're not logged in. I am very disappointed to say the least, and also a bit confused.

My nervous system cannot handle those trainings.

But worst of all is that app menus are completely broken in terms of performance. Never seen a game where you click on a button and waiting for 15-20 seconds till something will change on the screen as it's tries to load other menu.

If you want to warmup, way to go. 
If you want to improve, no way to go.

Pros: 
- You can shoot 
- many trainings

Cons: 
- Pay to get any feedback (not once, but monthly).
- Some trainings are rough, because as a colourblind person, I can barely see half-transparent with no shadow and flat texture of blue ball on blue background.
- People are cheating to be first on the leaderboard, hahaha.
- Forcing me to use other language (my locale, but translation is sooooo baaaad. Let me try to give you an  example of how it sounds like: "Do game/make options/tokens/go exit"
- I have to google how to change language, because I couldn't find it.
- I was doing some recommended tasks and they gave me shooting donuts from donkin donuts. Wow, so pro! 
- Trainings are not telling you what to do and they have some secret namings like VT30S8C2 now figure out if you have follow, shoot, follow and shoot, follow and not shoot, shoot from one corner to the other etc. After one training got 0% (wow!), then after three trials I figure out what I have to do. Then Aimlab congratz me and said that I increased my skill by 95%. Man I'm the GOAT.

Seriously? 20 gigs? For an aim trainer..? 
Insane bloat and enshittification. 

You can literally just go online for this. Or find another, free, without any subscriptions, login requirements, or stupid microtransactions, aim trainer on Steam, mind you.
Piece of shit. Plus this likely can't run on mildly old hardware due to the obscene and COMPLETELY unnecessary hardware requirements and "great graphics".

If you want to get good at aiming, don't install this game. It's a waste of storage space.

This pissed me off so bad I had to google how to leave a steam review, because even that has a bunch of hurdles, can only do it from the store page and the game has to be shut down to do it. 

In terms of aim training, I think tracking is definitely one of the most powerful aiming skills that will have you improve the most. However, trying the tracking games had me foaming at the mouth.

Worst of all, in those garbage minigames that are poorly designed and don't do what they are supposed to, you can't even leave comments leaving feedback or reviews. Your opinion is unimportant and there is no way to share it.

they are made so stupid and frustrating. A lot of them make you lose points if you don't stop firing every time you don't slip off target. That's a brain dead stupid and frustrating addition some low iq people made. 

I think it just adds extra stipulations to playing, making it more difficult to play, just to create avenues to make your score go down, and to venues for autistic people to get really high scores playing in weird and unnatural ways that doesn't benefit anyone just for the sake of having a really high score on this minigame alone and nothing else anywhere ever. 

Same thing with the tracking behavior of the targets. They will go dominantly left or right until you move 5 feet on your mouse pad, making it difficult to play, making you make judging decisions, if its a good time to skate your mouse or if you're gonna lose too many points. Again. This goofy, stupid, tracking behavior, just makes you bad at this tracking minigame, which has no bearing on any game ever. The point of aim labs is to create similar environments where you can hone in your skills. Not create a unique goofy environment where you hone skills that make you annoyed, make your wrist cramp, and help you nowhere. Most shooting games, people die in seconds, so where would it ever be useful to track for 5 mouse pads straight right over 25 seconds? How hard is it to measure total travel and keep the target in a range? 

soooo stupid, and so frustrating!
